titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: I went to the Cathedral at 8 a.m. and received the Holy Communion. My wife and my guests went with me. I was particularly pleased to notice that Professor Bacon, who is a Congregationalist, communicated. After breakfast William motored me to Lingen, where I preached to the congregation of villagers at a choral celebration. I had expected Mattins, and my sermon was determined by the first lesson. This ruffled me, and I was not well–pleased to notice the linen vestments & divers interpolations in the service. But who dares so much as whisper that Rubricks should be obeyed? The weather which had been most hostile when we travelled to Lingen improved wonderfully, & we drove back to Hereford in sunshine.

James brought the Judge, Lord Coleridge, to tea. I had some interesting conversation with him. When he had gone, I had scant time to get myself in order for preaching at Evensong at St Mary's Mission Church, Holmer. Ella, Mrs Waterfield, & Prof. Bacon accompanied me. The little church was well–filled, and, as soon as I had suppressed the coughing, the congregation was very attentive.
Wynne Willson and Mrs Lilley came in to supper: and we had much pleasant talk. The new Dean seems disposed to be friendly and loyal. His wife will certainly be popular.
